reference.title: resourceid
reference.shortdesc: The <resourceid> element provides an identifier for applications that must use their own identifier scheme, such as context-sensitive help systems and databases.

section.p: Versions of DITA before 1.3 used the @id attribute on the <resourceid> element to specify an ID for an external application. This use of the @id attribute is deprecated in favor of using the @appid attribute.

section.title: Contains
section.p: The content model of this element may differ based on where it is used. Content model information is located here:

section.title: Contained By
section.p: The parents of this element may differ based on where it is used. Content model information is located here:

example.title: Example
example.p: In the following example, a topic is referenced by three applications.
example.codeblock: <prolog> <resourceid appid="sqlid00375" appname="dbaccess"/> <resourceid appid="sample" appname="otherApp1"/> <resourceid appid="sample" appname="otherApp2"/> </prolog>
example.p: A database application with a value of "dbaccess" for the @appname attribute references the topic using the ID "sqlid00375". Two other applications use the ID "sample"; differing values for the @appname attribute distinguish between these two applications and the <resourceid> elements that are associated with them.

If this topic is reused by another author, that author may associate additional <resourceid> elements with the topic by placing them in the map. For example, the following entry in the <topicmeta> indicates that (in addition to the values already specified in the topic), an application with the value of "Author-B-App" references the topic using the ID "FunNewId":<topicref href="sample.dita"> <topicmeta> <navtitle>Sample: adding a resourceid externally</navtitle> <resourceid appname="Author-B-App" appid="FunNewId"/> </topicmeta> </topicref>

stentry.p: Before DITA 1.3, this attribute specified a value used by a specific application to identify the topic. That usage is deprecated in favor of using the @appid attribute.

strow.stentry: A name for the external application that references the topic.
An ID used by an application to identify the topic.
